G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u202f19.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper in the Springfield District Court under G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 239, § 1A because the Premises are located in Springfield, and the acts complained of occurred within this judicial district.

G.L. c. 239, \u00a7\u202f1A.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper in the Springfield District Court under G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 239, § 1A because the Premises are located in Springfield, and the acts complained of occurred within this judicial district.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7\u202f14.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, a landlord may not “directly or indirectly interfere with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises,” and a substantial interference constitutes a breach.

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716\.proposition: Massachusetts courts recognize that “serious defects in essential services such as heat, electricity, or hot water” can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716\.support_reasoning: The case itself involves noise from a lounge rather than defects in heat, electricity, or hot water, but in explaining constructive eviction and breach of quiet enjoyment the court expressly cites Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Corp., describing it parenthetically as involving "failure to supply light, heat, power, and elevator services." By doing so, the Blackett court recognizes that serious failures in essential services can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, even without intent, thereby supporting the proposition indirectly through its characterization of prior Massachusetts precedent.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716\.relevant_excerpt: There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done. Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Corp., 340 Mass. 124, 127 (1959) (failure to supply light, heat, power, and elevator services).

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.proposition: Massachusetts courts recognize that “serious defects in essential services such as heat, electricity, or hot water” can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion does interpret G.L. c. 186, § 14’s phrase “quiet enjoyment” broadly and ties it to serious interferences with the character and value of the premises, but this particular case involves repeated sewage flooding, not defects in heat, electricity, or hot water. The court nowhere states or illustrates that serious defects in essential utility services (heat, electricity, hot water) constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. Thus, while the case supports a broad concept of quiet enjoyment, it does not specifically stand for the proposition about essential services identified in the claim.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ Winchester v. O’Brien, 266 Mass. 33, 36 (1929) (quoting from Brande v. Grace, 154 Mass. 210, 212 [1891]). … Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy.”

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 285 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: A landlord’s inaction may amount to interference when the defect substantially impairs the character of the tenancy.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The court explicitly holds that a landlord’s failure to act (its inaction) in the face of serious interference can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, and it ties that breach to situations where the interference “substantially impairs the character of the leased premises.” The opinion explains that liability may arise from what the landlord “failed to do” or “permitted to be done,” and applies that principle to the landlord’s alleged failure to take measures against drug activity in common areas that rendered the premises unusable.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold… Thus, a landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’… If the defendant failed to take any action… then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Cohen v. Werner, 82 Mass. App. Ct. 283,.raw_text: Cohen v. Werner, 82 Mass. App. Ct. 283, 287 (2012)
Cohen v. Werner, 82 Mass. App. Ct. 283,.proposition: A landlord’s inaction may amount to interference when the defect substantially impairs the character of the tenancy.
Cohen v. Werner, 82 Mass. App. Ct. 283,.support_reasoning: The quoted opinion is a Massachusetts criminal case (Commonwealth v. Basey) involving aggravated rape and joint venture/joint enterprise liability. It does not concern landlord-tenant law, defects in leased premises, or interference with tenancy, and therefore cannot support a proposition about a landlord’s inaction constituting interference. The citation to Cohen v. Werner appears to be mismatched with the provided text, which is unrelated to that civil landlord-tenant principle.
Cohen v. Werner, 82 Mass. App. Ct. 283,.relevant_excerpt: The entire opinion excerpt deals with facts surrounding an aggravated rape, the sufficiency of evidence for joint venture/joint enterprise, and related criminal law standards; it contains no discussion of landlords, defects in premises, or interference with tenancy.

Hemingway v. Boston Hous. Auth., 363 Mas.raw_text: Hemingway v. Boston Hous. Auth., 363 Mass. 184, 199 (1973)
Hemingway v. Boston Hous. Auth., 363 Mas.proposition: Electrical service is an essential condition of human habitation under Massachusetts law.
Hemingway v. Boston Hous. Auth., 363 Mas.support_reasoning: This concurrence discusses that the State Sanitary Code ‘fixes minimum standards of fitness of structures for human habitation’ and that landlords are obliged to meet those minimum standards, but it does not specifically single out electrical service as an ‘essential condition of human habitation.’ The opinion talks about compliance with the Code in general terms rather than identifying particular services (like electricity) as essential, so it is at most indirect support and not clear authority for the specific proposition stated.
Hemingway v. Boston Hous. Auth., 363 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “Since 1960 dwelling units have been subject to the State Sanitary Code… The Code, which has the force of law and applies throughout the Commonwealth, fixes minimum standards of fitness of structures for human habitation.… It expressly places the burden on the owner to comply with the prescribed minimum physical standards for rented dwelling units.”

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 201 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: Electrical service is an essential condition of human habitation under Massachusetts law.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns heat and hot water outages as breaches of the implied warranty of habitability and discusses habitability generally, but it never addresses electrical service at all. While the court characterizes shelter and habitable conditions as necessities, it does not identify electricity as an essential condition of human habitation or make any holding specific to electrical service. Therefore, this case does not provide direct authority for the specific proposition about electrical service.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “Nevertheless, we note that the landlord’s liability without fault is merely an economic burden; the tenant living in an uninhabitable building suffers a loss of shelter, a necessity. More importantly, the warranty of habitability is not designed to penalize the landlord for misbehavior. In the rent abatement context, the doctrine imposes a duty quite apart from notions of moral sanction or deterrence.”

Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.raw_text: Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987)
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to damages including rent abatement, reimbursement of out-of-pocket costs, and statutory damages of not less than three months’ rent or actual damages, whichever is greater, pursuant to Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987) and Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (1997).

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to damages including rent abatement, reimbursement of out-of-pocket costs, and statutory damages of not less than three months’ rent or actual damages, whichever is greater, pursuant to Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987) and Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (1997).
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.support_reasoning: Al‑Ziab addresses whether a violation of the lead paint statute automatically constitutes a violation of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, and whether attorney’s fees under § 14 are available on that basis. It does not discuss or award rent abatement, reimbursement of out‑of‑pocket costs, or statutory damages of three months’ rent or actual damages; indeed, those types of remedies are not analyzed in this opinion. Thus, it does not support the specific remedial proposition claimed.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.relevant_excerpt: General Laws c. 111, §§ 190-199…imposes strict liability on landlords for damages caused by poisoning from lead paint, and provides for treble damages if a landlord has been notified of the presence of lead paint and fails to correct it as provided by the statute. G. L. c. 111, § 199… Significantly, the statute makes no provision for the payment of attorney’s fees… Were we to accept the plaintiffs’ argument, all landlords held strictly liable under the lead paint statute would necessarily be required to pay the attorney’s fees of the tenant. That result is inconsistent with the statutory scheme…

Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959\.raw_text: Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959 (1985)
Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959\.proposition: Defendant acted with knowledge of the defect and failed to act within a reasonable time following notice, which constitutes willful neglect under Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959 (1985).

G.L. c. 239, \u00a7\u202f8A.proposition: Defendant’s acts and omissions also violate the standards expressed in G.L. c. 239, § 8A; G.L. c. 111, § 127L; and 105 C.M.R. 410.351, which require landlords to maintain electrical facilities in safe and operable condition.

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7\u202f127L.proposition: Defendant’s acts and omissions also violate the standards expressed in G.L. c. 239, § 8A; G.L. c. 111, § 127L; and 105 C.M.R. 410.351, which require landlords to maintain electrical facilities in safe and operable condition.

105\u202fC.M.R.\u202f410.351.proposition: Defendant’s acts and omissions also violate the standards expressed in G.L. c. 239, § 8A; G.L. c. 111, § 127L; and 105 C.M.R. 410.351, which require landlords to maintain electrical facilities in safe and operable condition.

Balsavich v. Local 170 Teamsters Welfare.raw_text: Balsavich v. Local 170 Teamsters Welfare Fund, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 722, 728 (2016)
Balsavich v. Local 170 Teamsters Welfare.proposition: Defendant’s acts and omissions also violate the standards expressed in G.L. c. 239, § 8A; G.L. c. 111, § 127L; and 105 C.M.R. 410.351, which require landlords to maintain electrical facilities in safe and operable condition.
Balsavich v. Local 170 Teamsters Welfare.support_reasoning: The opinion is an OUI criminal case about the admissibility of ambulance and hospital records under G.L. c. 233, §§ 79 and 79G and the sufficiency of evidence of operation. It does not discuss landlord-tenant law, G.L. c. 239, § 8A, G.L. c. 111, § 127L, or 105 C.M.R. 410.351, nor any duty of landlords to maintain electrical facilities. The cited case therefore provides no authority for the proposition regarding landlord obligations under those housing and sanitary provisions.
Balsavich v. Local 170 Teamsters Welfare.relevant_excerpt: This appeal requires us to consider the application of two statutes governing the admissibility of medical records: G. L. c. 233, § 79, and G. L. c. 233, § 79G. Section 79, as appearing in St. 1959, c. 200, provides that “[r]ecords kept by hospitals, dispensaries or clinics, and sanatoria under section seventy of chapter one hundred and eleven shall be admissible ... so far as such records relate to . . . treatment and medical history.” ... We conclude that the records produced by Cataldo were admissible as proffered, under § 79G.

Leardi v. Brown, 394 Mass.\u202f151,\u20.proposition: Defendant’s conduct therefore constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, as recognized in Leardi v. Brown, 394 Mass. 151, 157 (1985) and Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855, 867 (1991).

Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass.\u202f855,\.proposition: Defendant’s conduct therefore constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, as recognized in Leardi v. Brown, 394 Mass. 151, 157 (1985) and Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855, 867 (1991).
